recommendations.text: High-intensity statin therapy should be initiated or continued in all patients with ACS unless contraindicated.
Dual antiplatelet therapy with aspirin and a P2Y12 inhibitor (clopidogrel, prasugrel, or ticagrelor) is recommended for patients with ACS.
ACE inhibitors (or ARBs if ACE inhibitor intolerant) are recommended for all patients with LVEF ≤40% and for those with hypertension, diabetes, or CKD.
Primary PCI is the preferred reperfusion strategy in patients with STEMI when it can be performed within 90 minutes of first medical contact.
An early invasive strategy (within 24 hours) is recommended for patients with UA/NSTEMI who have TIMI risk score ≥3 or other high-risk features.
Beta-blocker therapy should be initiated in the first 24 hours for patients with STEMI who do not have contraindications.
Supplemental oxygen should be administered only to patients with hypoxemia (SpO2 <94%).
It is reasonable to continue P2Y12 inhibitor therapy beyond 12 months in patients with ACS who have tolerated DAPT without bleeding complications.
Fibrinolysis is reasonable when PCI is not available within 120 minutes of first medical contact in patients with STEMI.
Routine use of oxygen supplementation in patients with ACS who do not have hypoxemia is not recommended.
Oral anticoagulation is recommended for patients with AF and CHA₂DS₂-VASc score ≥2 in men or ≥3 in women, unless contraindicated.
Rate control is reasonable as the initial strategy in the majority of patients with AF.
Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are recommended over warfarin for eligible patients with AF (except those with moderate-to-severe mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valve).
For patients with AF lasting >48 hours or of unknown duration, anticoagulation for ≥3 weeks before and ≥4 weeks after cardioversion is recommended.
Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE)-guided cardioversion is an alternative to pre-cardioversion anticoagulation for patients with AF >48 hours.
Beta-blockers or non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (diltiazem, verapamil) are recommended for rate control in patients with AF.
Rhythm control is reasonable in symptomatic patients with AF to improve symptoms and quality of life.
Digoxin can be useful for rate control in patients with AF and heart failure with reduced ejection fraction or hypotension.
Amiodarone can be useful for rhythm control in patients with AF, particularly after cardiac surgery.
Routine anticoagulation is not recommended for patients with AF and CHA₂DS₂-VASc score of 0 in men or 1 in women.

hfref.title: Heart Failure with Reduced Ejection Fraction

recommendations.text: ACE inhibitors (or ARBs or ARNI) are recommended for all patients with HFrEF to reduce morbidity and mortality.
Evidence-based beta-blockers are recommended for all patients with HFrEF to reduce morbidity and mortality.
Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists (MRAs) are recommended in patients with HFrEF who remain symptomatic despite optimal ACE inhibitor and beta-blocker therapy.
SGLT2 inhibitors are recommended for patients with HFrEF to reduce hospitalizations and cardiovascular death.

hfpef.title: Heart Failure with Preserved Ejection Fraction

recommendations.text: SGLT2 inhibitors can be beneficial to decrease HF hospitalizations in patients with HFpEF.
Management of hypertension, diabetes, and obesity is recommended in patients with HFpEF.
ARBs can be useful to decrease HF hospitalizations in patients with HFpEF.
MRAs may be considered to decrease HF hospitalizations in select patients with HFpEF.
Lifestyle modifications are recommended for all patients with elevated BP or hypertension.
Target BP should be <130/80 mmHg for most adults with confirmed hypertension and known CVD or 10-year ASCVD risk ≥10%.
First-line antihypertensive medications include thiazide or thiazide-like diuretics, ACE inhibitors, ARBs, or CCBs.
Combination therapy with 2 first-line agents of different classes is reasonable as initial therapy for patients with stage 2 hypertension.
ICD therapy is recommended for secondary prevention in survivors of VT/VF not due to a reversible cause.
Urgent cardioversion is recommended for sustained VT with hemodynamic compromise.
Catheter ablation is reasonable for recurrent sustained monomorphic VT despite antiarrhythmic drug therapy.
Vagal maneuvers should be the initial treatment for stable SVT with regular, narrow QRS complexes.
Adenosine is recommended if vagal maneuvers fail to terminate SVT.
Catheter ablation is reasonable for recurrent SVT that is drug-refractory or when the patient prefers definitive therapy.
Permanent pacing is recommended for third-degree AV block at any anatomic level associated with symptoms.
Permanent pacing is recommended for second-degree Mobitz II AV block.
Permanent pacing is reasonable for asymptomatic third-degree AV block at any anatomic level with escape rate <40 bpm.
Permanent pacing is indicated for acquired third-degree AV block with symptoms attributable to bradycardia.
Permanent pacing is indicated for Mobitz type II second-degree AV block regardless of symptoms.
Permanent pacing is reasonable for marked first-degree AV block (>300 ms) with left ventricular dysfunction and symptoms.
All patients with arrhythmias should have a 12-lead ECG and assessment for reversible causes.
Electrolyte abnormalities (particularly potassium and magnesium) should be corrected in patients with arrhythmias.
Echocardiography is reasonable for patients with new-onset arrhythmias to assess for structural heart disease.
All patients with SIHD should receive guideline-directed medical therapy including antiplatelet therapy, ACE inhibitor/ARB, beta-blocker, and statin.
High-intensity statin therapy is recommended for all patients with SIHD unless contraindicated.
Cardiac catheterization is reasonable for patients with SIHD who have unacceptable angina despite GDMT.
